The mental health resources and benefits are top in the industry and managers and staff are being taught how to support one another in ways that honor mental wellbeing. The award winning HeartU resource provides thousands of growth and enrichment resources, including Harvard Business Reviews, live webinars, audiobooks, full length books and articles, podcasts, etc. Part of HeartU is CareerU, which provides many resources for planning one's career, creating a development plan, working on executive presence, interview and resume writing tips and more. AHA is also able to leverage McKinsey's Connected Leaders Academy suite of leadership programs and other well-known programs to develop leaders. Fundraisers can earn very large incentive bonuses when goals are reached. Onboarding program is thorough, and they assign an onboarding buddy to help new hires get acclimated. 10 Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) as well as a mentoring program help employees express themselves and stay connected.

I witnessed 8 positions turn over with one as a double turnover and another opened for 6 months. Working at the American Heart Association has altered my fundraising outlook. The “sell sell sell and by the way, here is our mission” practice ruined my joy in a mission I can believe and back, and I’m not sure that will ever change.

review_title: Missional Organization with Room to Improve
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: Pay is moderate. Benefits are excellent - including 403(b) and longevity is rewarded. Offers flexibility including remote and hybrid. Senior leaders communicate their appreciation for employees, including adding extra holidays. The culture is positive and pro-family, including an ERG for parents, which has been a source of emotional support. Mental health and stress support are available and encouraged. Software and laptops are up to date - really great tech support. Rare evening and weekend emails. Meetings team works longer hours around conferences. Opportunities to switch jobs are available,
cons: Taking time off is challenging due to workload and poor planning. Too few people doing too much work leads to bottlenecks. When one person is out there is no one else to do that job. Submitting tickets to overworked departments means it takes weeks to months to get things done. Correcting mistakes made by others is a prolonged process. Employees identify ways to improve but change is slow and cumbersome. I can see some leaders making effort to improve working conditions (the culture), hire people, and set people up for success. In some areas people seem set up to fail. Morale is low in some areas due to overwork and exhaustion. High turnover in some areas leads to loss of institutional knowledge. Would recommend the AHA to those who want a purpose driven job requiring intensive hours, with high demands.

After a layoff which eliminated 1/3 Of the staff in the office, former employees were still allowed to ‘volunteer’ which meant coming in and doing their old job for free. review_title: Culture of Mediocrity is Alive and Well
pros:
This is one of the easiest jobs you'll ever have. The standards are low and there is no accountability. People come into the Dallas office (National Center) after 9A and the parking lot is 80% empty at 5P. 

Miss a deadline? Try harder next time. Go overbudget? They're barely tracked so not to worry.  Don't respond to emails or phone calls? Gosh, you must just be too busy. Confrontation is avoided, and those who speak up are exiled. 

But don't get me wrong - the work/life balance is amazing because you barely have to do any work to excel. 

The AHA is a good case study for why heritage nonprofits across the country are struggling to compete in today's competitive environment.
cons:
If you are the type of person who likes to be challenged with new, innovative work, this is not the place for you. If seeing others get excused for missing deadlines and doing sloppy work drives you crazy, this is not the place for you. People are allowed to be rude and unresponsive. People work in silos and integration is barely existent. There are no opportunities to grow in place; you can only get promoted if you move teams or departments. 

But, hey, if you want to work in a culture of mediocrity, then this is the place for you.

pros:

home office opportunities

review_title: A National organization that feels like a small community
job_title: quality and systems improvement director in San Antonio, TX
pros:
The AHA/ASA is a non-profit organization, so I feel like all the work I'm doing is for a great cause, one that is very important to me. Being a science-based organization, decisions are not made lightly and are not based in subjectivity. I love working for an organization that I can observe benefit my own community through research funding, community outreach, and legislative work.

My supervisors and coworkers have been incredibly supportive since day one. They have all helped to remove barriers and everyone jumps in to help each other when needed rather than competing.

AHA/ASA has the benefit of being a National organization which people recognize and look to for guidance. There is opportunity for recognition and collaboration across the country as well as internationally. However, there are smaller teams throughout the organization that focus on the health of the local communities and support healthcare providers even in the most rural places.
cons: As a large organization, sometimes changes can take a while to come to fruition. However, ideas and suggestions are heard and elevated to appropriate levels.

review_title: National Center - limited career growth & surprisingly cut throat
job_title: Marketing Manager Nutrition in Dallas, TX
pros: Excellent benefits and work/life balance, good cause--which you have to weigh against the low pay.
cons:
- Leadership values outside agency expertise over employees' professional perspective.

review_title: Best non Profit is not True!
pros: Long Holiday's off and Benefits
cons: Work life balence is untrue,high turnover in all departments especially Human Resources,micro-management is a way for untrained managers to put theur work off on you,no accountability with uper management and they promote within to stiff employees out of competitive salaries,no pay grade because is promoted within you can only obtain 5% of your salary depending on the promotion and job title you obtain. Very untrustworthy groups you work in they praise you and stab you in the back at the same time, hard to get promoted if you're not in a clique,your not promoted by what you know but who's butt your kissing. pros: Work does good in the community. Job offers great experiences like traveling across the nation, meeting amazing volunteers, and working on historic campaigns. Great benefits package. Great place to start a career or gain work experience.  Great at promoting work/life balance.
cons:
Corporate/for-profit environment and aggressive goals with non-profit salaries and resources.  Fund raising is a major priority no matter what department or job title you have, expect to participate in fund raising activities in some capacity. 
Only eligible for raises or promotions once a year.  Very limited opportunities for career advancement if you are a health strategies staff because of the limited positions. pros:
Strong mission and excellent advocacy efforts throughout the US. 
Great benefits package including two week winter holiday break in addition to paid-time off.
cons: How do you tell your friends you enjoy your job but you hate the politics of working for this organization. Well that's how I felt about working for the AHA. And as I've come to find out It the politics and the stress that equals a pot of scalding hot water aren't just limited to any one affiliate but seems to be rampant across the AHA. After losing my job for poor performance (although I was a top producing and competent fundraiser) the management team saw it fit to change office locks and tell staff not to allow me in the office .. presumably so the post-it notes supply wouldn't be depleted overnight.

pros: Good Mission; Teaching children to garden and enjoy vegatables, decreasing food deserts, positive impact on legislation, non-smoking laws, AED's in public places, etc. Encouraging companies to have walking trails and allow employees more physical activity at work.  Encouraging healthy choices, etc.
cons: misleading to donors. One manager had 4 people quit in two months by saying "F you I quit!" yet, senior management backed them and assumed that it wasn't management, it had to be a string of crazy people, despite the fact that they had been with the company for years.  HOSTILE work environment.  I felt PHYSICALLY THREATENED on MULTIPLE occasions!  Don't ask questions, it's considered disrespectful.  A lot of Micro-management.

review_title: Lots of opportunity for talented people
job_title: Affiliate Fundraising Staff in Dallas, TX
pros: Salary and benefits are great; rewards and advancement are there for people that know how to acccomplish goals and work well with others; wonderful, dedicated staff and volunteers;  a compelling mission; leaders that care about the staff and the mission; flexibility for staff in hours and location if the person performs well
cons: There are some former staff members that are writing on this site. Some people think that working for a nonprofit means relatively easy work. That is not true. When people find that a job is not for them, they should exit, but not bash the company. That is not good for them or for others. No one workplace fits all types of people, and unfortunately, there will sometimes be managers we don;t work well with. There are many happy people here that love working for the AHA.  The AHA is in the top echelon of Non-Profits to Work For according to Non-Profit Times and as judged by current employees every year.  Employee Engagement survey results are excellent.  Check these out for a more complete perspective.

review_title: Not for profit engine on very for-profit chassis
pros: Co-workers, salary (overall), mission, benefits
cons: Management - especially upper-mid and mid-levels; Typical corporate demands without the corporate perks and pay; Accusatory and divisive VPs and managers, Lack of clear direction causes delay and frustration.

job_title: Youth Market Director/Regional Director in Chicago, IL
pros: The AHA has a great mission and the management is very focused and they make a concerted effort to be sure donor dollars are spent  wisely . Staff and coworkers, in general, are really great people and believe strongly in the mission
cons: There is not a good balance between work and home life. The hours can be very long. There is a great deal of pressure placed on fundraisers to meet goal so you will need to be a person who handles that type of stress well. The burn-out rate for nonprofit fundraisers is quite high.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: I've found the AHA to be an incredible place to work.  The people I get to work with - staff and volunteers - are so committed to our mission and continuously push me to deliver the very best outcomes possible.  Goals are ambitious and I'm reminded every day by our survivors why that's important.  One day, we will be able to say that heart disease and stroke are no longer parts of our lives.  I'm very grateful to be a part of trying to make that happen.
cons: The flip side of having really ambitious goals is that it takes a ton of resilience and determination to keep going.  Again, that's where our amazing survivors, volunteers and staff help keep the focus on why we do what we do.

pros:
1 week off during Holidays.
Summer hours.
cons: Poor Management . Very unethical & dishonest management. This was probably the most unprofessional & unethical company I have never seen.   You would think this would be a wonderful place to work but don't be fooled. Employees are not appreciated at all and overworked . Although it is a 'health' organization, yours will not be taken into consideration. The stress level is very high and workers are over inundated. Ethics does not exist  at all here. Accepting this position was a bad decision and a waste of time, especially since I turned down another offer to take it. Huge mistake. I would definitely not recommend working here. Please do yourself a favor and  don't waste your time here.

job_title: Corporate Market Director in Denver, CO
pros: Funds raised to to a good cause.
cons:
Turnover.
Turnover tells you absolutely everything that you need to know about a company.  Ask them during your interview about how many people have held this position recently.   Lying (to employees and volunteers), manipulating, favoritism and even cheating to meet goals happens.  We were also told that we were required to work 12 hour days as well.  Emails will have to be reviewed by your manager for editing and changes  before they are sent to donors.  This will take days and all your work will be held up because of it.  Upper management leaves during the day to get their nails and hair done or go out to lunch, but will micromanage every move you make.

pros: Great cause! Some affiliates strongly encourage employee innovation and feedback and take it seriously.
cons: Very high-pressure at Natl. office where only a few are empowered to have a 'voice' to innovate or provide constructive feedback.

pros: Am I dreaming?  Is this job for real?  After working for decades in another field, I had no idea that full time jobs exist where employees feel appreciated and rewarded for their efforts!  AHA has blown my socks off with it's family atmosphere, extensive onboarding training, top-notch benefits, workplace fitness efforts and management that really cares about the organization's mission and realizes that its employees are the key to the mission's success.  High ethical standards and accountability are apparent from top to bottom - not just lip service!  I give it the AHA highest marks!
cons: The sheer number of programs and efforts that this organization undertakes is mind-boggling and somewhat overwhelming to a new employee, particularly those who have never worked for a large corporation.  To AHA's credit - they realize that there's a learning curve and make every effort to manage new employee expectations accordingly.

pros: The Bonus Structure is awesome - up to 20% of your salary if you meet your goal! Important Mission and great volunteers.
cons: Absolutely horrible work environment. The more cut throat you are the better you are liked by senior management.  Goals are unattainable and you're only as good as your last number.  Staff are treated poorly and are expected to work 100 hours a week with no gratitude. Last year, there was a Challenge to raise 1 million new dollars, which had never been done before.  One market achieved over $900K new and they were not even acknowledged bc they didn't achieve that magic number. One top executive has been accused of sexual harassment, discrimination, not paying women and men equally, and verbal abuse by dozens of people over the years and is still employed seemingly because he achieves financial goals.  Money is valued over all else, including the mission.

pros: Everything this company does is relevant to the mission of helping everyone to live longer, healthier lives.  There is an intense focus on raising funds in the developments departments, however, it is to be able to make that much more of a difference.  Strategic focus does create changes in operations, but if you are flexible and willing to try new things then change won't bother you.  Pay and benefits are extremely competitive in this field.
cons: The spirit of collaboration is dependent on which affiliate you work under.  Mobility is very hard and only those within the Development field really even get considered.  Being a team player affords you many new experiences and talents, however, you never get credit for things not under your own job responsibilities. Senior Management definitely has their favorites, which can make for a political environment at times.

pros: Time off for Christmas if you can make it that long.  The time will be used for much needed metal and emotional stress.
cons: You name it!!! MANAGEMENT, Management and Did I say mention Management!  These are individuals that would never make it in a real company or organization with a true sense of what not to do when you are a manager.  If someone is promoted to a management position it's because they literally scratched and clawed their way up.  Beating down their employees is given a "high-five" and honorable mention.

review_title: Too much sales for a non-profit
job_title: Special Event Director in Allentown, PA
pros: Good pay for a non-profit position. The overall mission of the society is great and something to be proud of. The daily work with volunteers and survivors is something that can not be reproduced.
cons: The company requires that their staff act like a very aggressive salespeople instead of behaving like a fundraising role. They do not respect their donors and/or the communities in which they have events. The level of drama and mid-level management nonsense is beyond ridiculous. Their priorities are very mixed up.

pros: Used to be a family orientated company. Employees are close like family, everyone tries to help each other out when times are tough.
cons: Tons of reconfigurations and layoffs. Changes are never ending and jobs are being lost. Feel as if there will be another shake up soon.  We are all in fear for our jobs. Lower managment is poor and some of them do not know what they are doing. Those who do nothing, get promoted and those who work hard are repremanded.

pros:
AHA is big about finding culture and job fits for its staff. It's a good reason why so many of the staff have been here so long (20+ years).

The mission drives everything we do.

Leadership give you the opportunity to grow and mistakes - Fail fast.

A lot of collaboration between departments and National Center/field.
cons:

pros: AHA is a big corporate machine that do care about the employees.  Nancy is a good CEO. She is very approachable.  She always remember people's name.  And best of all she listens to people very well. The compensation is really good.  Anyone will be happy here.
cons: You can tell that the politic kicks in sometime on certain decisions. Watching bad decision being made on how to spend the money is really hard, especially when you just stayed up till 4am the night before trying to work on a project that hopefully will bring in more donations.

pros: Great Benefits, which is what keeps it on the "best workplace" lists.
cons: My manager was consistently dishonest. I noticed this from the very beginning, so I began recording all of our conversations to could keep track of her expectations. This is my advice. Record and document everything. She started blaming me for her missteps. I scheduled a meeting with HR for advice on how to handle the situation, and they took notes, asked for more information on the misuse of donor funds that had occurred and then terminated my employment. As if that wasn't enough, AHA contested my unemployment benefits with the Texas Workforce Commission, stating that I had left and canceled a meeting. I canceled a meeting that I had scheduled to attend a meeting my boss requested and then the meeting I "left" is recorded, clearly demonstrating that I was there for the entirety. Thankfully, these false allegations are documented thoroughly., but it's nothing like learning the true colors of a company that will kick you when you're down. This was a very disheartening experience from the non-profit industry that presents a charitable persona.

review_title: Great opportunity within a great organization
job_title: Youth Market Director in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The AHA is very much driven by a clear set of values, and a very central, over-arching mission.  I feel very fortunate to be involved in such inspiring work.
cons: It is a "learn as you go" type of position.  As someone who really wants to be an expert at their position before jumping in with both feet, I felt a little overwhelmed when I started.

pros: Some flexibility if working out in the field.  Week off at Christmas. Good PTO . AHA does wonderful work in advocacy and education changing lives every day.
cons: Recent study shows a 75% turnover rate in the first 6 months of employment. Intense pressure placed upon fundraising staff routinely causing health problems and family distress.  Running joke that AHA works to reduce heart disease EXCEPT for it's own staff.  Very sad but true.  This is top down poor management with little regard for the personal lives of its employees.  AHA does such important work, too bad this is the reality of the workplace.

review_title: Good Place to Work & Build a Career
pros: Benefits, Passionate Mission and Volunteers, Strong relationships with science community, strong brand value!
cons: Many candidates and new hires complain that AHA takes way too long to fill open positions.  Sadly, some VP's and Directors are not qualified to lead teams, with very poor interpersonal skills with some exhibiting bullying behaviors. That was a real issue in my department the last five years before I left.

pros: Life-saving mission and great volunteers/survivors who are compelled to do great work.
cons: There is no upward mobility for staff in support positions. You will rarely be referred to by your name as "admin" is sufficient. If you have a manager who focuses on your professional development, you are in the minority. The mission is great but the Chicago office is a death trap. Turnover is a serious issue - in my 16 months at the organization, I saw over 20 staff members rotate in and out of the office. Don't expect any support or understanding from HR. Getting a week off at Christmas means that you do not get many other holidays off. Expect the rug to be pulled out from under you at any moment.

pros: The cause is important and at the national level this organization leads the way in important research and legislation.
cons:
If your regional manager is crap, your experience will be horrible.  AHA is one of those charities that does everything they can to cut overhead costs. It's admirable to see from the outside, but on the inside, as an employee, it creates a lot of stress and pressure to just do a TON of work with very limited resources.  They rely heavily on volunteers. HEAVILY.  If you don't have volunteers you can count on you're screwed.  Very driven by the bottom line and finding information within their internal database is a nightmare.  Their training is thorough to the point that it's almost like having a second job - someone in the company compared it to trying to drink water through a fire hose.  Again, because you are intentionally short staffed, you need to be able to know and do EVERYTHING.  It's insane.  

Events will run you down and exhaust you.  I worked overtime SO MUCH, off the clock, just to get stuff done.  Nobody else is there to do it.  My job was one that had been left vacant for so long that nothing had been done and I had 2 months to pull a giant event together that normally requires a year of work.  Did I have sympathy?  Did I get any sense of support from my management?  No.  In fact, hearing them critique my event afterward was maddening seeing as it was 100% a miracle that it happened at all.

Dealing with a lot of different managers will be maddening, depending upon which level you're at.  I was tremendously happy when I was able to find another job and leave.  

If you are toward the bottom of the totem pole, be aware that a bad manager can blame crap on you and middle management will likely buy into it.  CYA at all times.

pros:
AHA has a wonderful mission, and the work is rewarding. Pay and benefits are generous, even in comparison with for-profit companies.

You'll meet some truly incredible people, too!
cons:
AHA has a wonderful mission, but the organization doesn’t seem to practice what it preaches. While your standard workweek is allegedly 37.5 hours, it’s nearly impossible to stick to that schedule given the amount of work and chronic under staffing.

Promotions are seemingly determined by “who you know”, not by actual ability or aptitude. The end result is under-qualified, insecure supervisors who cannot tolerate dissension, or even simple questions.  

Upper-management seems oblivious to toxic environments, but in reality, they do not care.

review_title: American Heart Association is a great place to work
pros: My position offers flexibility of work place either home, on the road, or in the office depending on need. The AHA offers a robust insurance and benefits package - including retirement options, life insurance, and health insurance options, along with time-off accrual. The organization strives for staff to have a "work/life balance" and have a quality experience working for the organization. The mission of the organization is what brings many to work for the AHA/ASA - working to improve health for all.
cons: Annual goals for each department are made in each affiliate, however the overall approval must come from the national office whereas there may be a disconnect. However, the organization has ongoing work to streamline processes and staff on a local level hope for improvement.

pros: Supporting the mission of saving lives through education and programs.
cons: Little to no work life balance as they claim to have it but youou better make sure you are "saying" the right things because there are a lot of cliques and only even if you are doing an amazing job if you are not in the clique, things will not be fun. Tons of politics, skewing information, misleading donors to get management off your back so they can meet their goals to bonus. Management is flavor of the day and promoted off how well the clique likes you and if you had good numbers for at least one campaign season, no matter what you had to do to get those number.

pros: AHA has a great mission and many thousands of dedicated volunteers who are ready to support staff.  Non-managerial staff can enjoy a rewarding career with a good compensation and benefit package. Don't misunderstand though, it is AHA's compensation policy to pay in the 50-75% range of a comparable for profit position.
cons:
Program management is unstable. Management is incapable of determining a  direction that will remain for more than 1-3 years. The frequent  restructures, job duty changes, and de-emphasis of positions that were critical only weeks before, prove that any decision will be fully reversed within a few years.

Most VP and EVPs do not understand the staff-volunteer partnerships and the way those relationships are developed and maintained. The VP and EVP staff are singularly focused on their annual bonus.

If you are a donor or in a non-management position, you need to be aware that your managers Do Receive Annual Bonuses based on revenue.

pros: great people to work with, not a hostile environment, adaptive to change, a mission worth working for, benefits are great.
cons: So much mention about work-life balance, however they do not practice what they preach.  You’re expected to work until the job gets done regardless.  They offer a 37.5 hour work week with an ability to work from home…if you only work 37.5 hours per week consider yourself lucky and if you are able to work from home you are constantly reminded that it is a perk/benefit and not a “right.”  The pay is below market value and this is evident in the Managers/Directors they hire.  They hire inexperienced Manager/Directors because they are cheap and then do not provide training.

review_title: Major culture change with new CEO
job_title: Senior Vice President in Dallas, TX
pros: Wonderful cause, mission, important work. Great company for women and working moms. Competitive salary in non-profit world and top-notch benefits.
cons: Negative, cut-throat culture since change in CEO and multiple EVPs. Zero work-life balance. Culture is based in secrecy and a "lead by fear" mentality.

pros: Supports a good cause for cardiovascular health.
cons: American Heart Association National Headquarters follows unethical, unfair, and discriminatory hiring practices. Before I got hired there, the notorious recruiters, who should be fired, constantly lied to me about the status of my applications. I later found out that many of the job postings that had publicly been posted were "fake" job postings and either were already pre-filled by an internal candidate or was actually not a real job to begin with. The only way I got hired was through a reliable contact in this organization. They should stop with these unethical practices because other reputable companies, and healthcare professionals will talk and tarnish AHA's name and brand if they are not careful. This place is filled with office politics, nepotism, favoritism, bad management practices, and is just..... pure hell. Thank God, I have a backup plan because I will soon be leaving to better green pastures.

review_title: The Heart Association just wasn't a fit for me.
pros: You get to work with some terrific volunteers.  Most full time employees have their hearts in the right place.
cons: Management by consensus is not management.  Upper-level and mid-level management have inflated titles and are overpaid for the value they provide.  Management provides little to no leadership.  The organization needs to realize there is a difference between a skill set and a warm body - filling a need because you have a warm body but not the correct skill set is a recipe for disaster and results in too many "home grown" solutions.

review_title: A cross between extremely political and extremely rewarding
job_title: Director Product Development in Dallas, TX
pros:
Extremely rewarding - you can and do make a difference in people's lives
The research, the Guidelines and the training programs literally impact the difference between life and death.  As an employee you have a part in that.
cons: Extremely political.  To the point where it is difficult to get things done if you are not the flavor of the month.  Very entrenched "that's not the way we do it here" attitude, to the point where it has kept the organization in the dark regarding other issues and organization that are competitive for donation dollars.  An overwhelmingly fear-based organization.

pros: The role is extremely challenging, each person is responsible for managing a multiple county territory.  Vacation/PTO time is available, the week between Christmas and New Year's is a given every year in addition to earning hours each month.  Mission support is personally rewarding.
cons: The compensation is lower than if one worked in the private business sector, but that's one of the cons of working for a non-profit.  Micro-managing seems to be rampant in all divisions.  Stuck doing a lot of administrative work.

pros: Nice concept of working for a Non-Profit for a cause.  There are some really nice people that come to work for AHA.
cons:
The really nice people that start at AHA tend to leave because AHA is not as it appears.  

Management needs to be reviewed.  Managers at the American Heart Association are not held accountable for their actions.  A manager is always right even if they are wrong.  Heads turn when it comes to managers.  If an employee makes a mistake and they are not managers they are held to a different set of standards and heads roll. 

It's all about how much money you can bring in and who you know not what you know or how you do your job or present yourself.

pros: I enjoy working with my immediate team. In my experience, the salary is pretty good for a nonprofit. The employee education plan is pretty good.
cons:
The best advice I can give anyone interviewing for any job here is to ask during your interview about turnover both within your team and within your department, and why. Why is this job open? How long has everyone else on your team been with AHA? Do you believe the answers you get? 
Know that turnover rates within some departments can be 25 percent annually or higher, and dealing with long-term employees (longer than 5 years) can be its own issue. Nothing is done about the fact that high turnover rates indicate poor management.

pros:
I am excited to step in to my office everyday and my team members are like family members. Great managers who are like mentors and they are open to my career aspirations and what i would like to work on. 

We have internal promotions even if it is a lateral move
One week paid time off for one week in December
Best Doctors helpline to call in and ask for any medical related research and help
Personal assistant helpline to help us assist in anything other than work related too
$150/year & 12 Wellness hours if you live healthy and excercise
cons: Total Salary may not be competitive when you compare it to a for profit organization but you have good work life balance and great work culture to compensate that.

review_title: They pay well, but you pay for it
pros: Salary is better than at most other national non-profits. Leave benefits, etc are good too. Insurance good, but not the absolute best in the industry. If you want to work hard, so all other jobs seem easier, spend a few years at AHA.  If you are able to reach your revenue goal they provide good $ incentives.
cons:
Aggressive to the point that it demotivates many employees.  Your experience here really depends on your manager and affiliate.  Walks the walk less than other non-profits and companies around hiring for diversity.  

I have to warn against working in the Nashville office while the current Executive Director is there.  Does not inspire or grow her team members, is vindictive and is the cause of excessive turnover.

pros: Fantastic benefits for employee and family, lots pf pto time, week off between Christmas and New Year's (MWA Affiliate), and irs suggested mileage reimbursement.
cons: There seems to be a terrible "rash" of terminations going on in the Midwest. Excellent employees are being fired for no apparent reason. Bogus infractions are being fabricated and then failure is served on a silver platter. Documents being given to an employee are not the same documents sent off to HR. Favoritism runs rampant. At the end of the day, it's not about funding research for the #1 killer, It's about goals met or not met. Unreasonable monthly sales goals are being established - people are worried about losing their jobs on a daily basis. Morale couldn't be any lower. People are baffled by management's decisions.

pros:

*great pay
*Strong Mission
*large organization with lots of resources and leading edge technology
*great training
cons:

*very long hours and unrealistic expectations for staff
*no work/life balance at all
*high stress-high pressure
*your job is at risk if you don't meet aggressive goals, so there's high turnover

pros: Mission is very important.  Great salary and benefits.  Lots of committed, passionate volunteers are willing to work hard to help organization.
cons: Many managers at the SVP, VP and Senior Director Level are horrible.  In this area, management positions have typically been hired from outside the organization.  Usually these new hires have never been managers and have not received the proper training on how to manage effectively.   Lots of ugly internal politics and some unethical behavior.  Some managers will do anything to achieve the overly aggressive fundraising goals.  Managers often take credit for work that their staff does without giving the appropriate credit due.  Organization does not value diversity in staff or volunteer leadership.  No work life balance.

review_title: The worst working experience of my professional career
pros: The work of the organization truly does save lives.
cons: The management team of the Mid Atlantic states leaves much to be desired.  It would make much more sense to have like size cities grouped together for the purpose of success comparisons.

review_title: Working here eats away at your soul
pros: The benefits are pretty good, it's nice to get the week of Christmas off. Technology is always great.  Some of the volunteers are great.
cons:
Management makes your life hell here. Nothing is good enough. The minute you're close to achieving your goal they change it so you can never get there. The goals are so unrealistic. There is no such thing as respect - some of the management would follow sponsors to a funeral if they thought it would get them more money.

I feel lucky to have survived. Worst job I've ever had!

job_title: Director of Community Health in Northport, NY
pros: The mission and work of the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association impacts all individuals.  it is constantly evolving with new research and there is a need to consistently learn to keep current. There is also the privilege of working with many incredible survivors who are willing to share their stories as well as the generous donors who allow us to continue our work.
cons: The ability to balance work and life is hard,  It is certainly not a 9-5 job.  we do not always have the tools available to do our job well.  Yearly reviews for fund raising has not be equitable.  Option for working from home should be equitable.  Some senior managers are more flexible than others.

review_title: You'll never BE enough, DO enough or FEEL good enough about your job!  HORRIBLE culture and AWFUL working environment!
pros:
Raising money to save lives is rewarding
Meeting survivors
Connecting with supportive members of the community
cons:
Zero work/life balance
HUGE egos running the organization
Angry/bitter managers who forget why the organization is raising money
Employees constantly berated for what they "could have done better"
Either bow down to management or lose your job, regardless of how well you're doing your job

pros: None.  Seriously, none.  I have nothing positive to say.
cons: This was by far the most political place I ever worked.  Ask the wrong person the wrong work-related question and you are basically written up, verbally reprimanded, or even fired.  I have never seen such exquitsitely sensitive people with such fragile egos.  The building itself is a leaking bug-infested shambles, boiling hot in some areas and freezing cold in others.  The break area is a joke.  Parking's a joke.  People in IT don't even have cubes; they hot-desk.  You can't reach out to anyone for help because of the unwritten rules and structure of the place so if you're the type who likes to get things done, work elsewhere.  If you're a BA or a PM, forget about having a life.  If you're in fundraising, you will be screamed at on a regular basis.

pros: Love working here!  I can contribute to the health and well being of my community and make a good living. Very professional organization and I feel a strong sense of pride when I tell others where I work. The innovative environment is not something I expected here and was a delightful surprise.   I like the fast pace.
cons: We are not always perfect but strive for continuous improvement in an ever changing environment.

review_title: A worthy organization with disappointing C-Suite
pros: Lots of great people dedicated to fighting heart disease.  You do feel you've done something good at the end of the day.  Can be a good place to work, depending on where you're located and what group you work with.
cons: Very tough to move up unless you're on the fund-raising side. Senior management seems more focused on getting their bonuses than anything else.  Very mercenary, selfish lot.  Really disappointing as leadership goes. Employees very much taken for granted.

pros: Good benefits (PTO, health insurance, and retirement matching) Work from home option, a great place to learn new skills and move laterally, overall positive work environment
cons: Many positions are so loosely structured that your duties are constantly changing. Although some co-workers are nice, others lack manners and will throw you under the bus to make themselves look good to volunteers and upper management. Your team lead may or may not have your back. Although work-life balance seems good at first, the longer you stay with the company, you'll find that you are overworked and underpaid. "Team players" are underappreciated and taken advantage of.

review_title: The momentum is building in Michigan
pros: There are some really dedicated people here.The volunteer base is also dedicated. The events around which the fundraising is based are good solid programs and there is a good flow of information and materials.
cons: Most staff need to juggle lots of activities at once and can do that well. There are high expectations for staff and a recent management shuffle will help the office morale. This should help the current staff  as they work toward goals.

pros: Some WFH days, some flexibility, located in a nice area, free lunches, decent pay.
cons: Toxic, cliquey environment, make you feel like you're inferior/not part of the team. Treat you as if certain jobs are beneath them, and its a hassle for them if you ask for help. If you don't mix well with the team, you're just another assistant. If you don't fully understand something and feel the need to ask questions, they make you feel incompetent. Senior/upper management are only worried about themselves and meeting their goals. Not just that, but people also talk badly about you behind your back. Overall, horrible experience.

pros: what they do for the community, the research that is conducted.  National office seems to have it more together than the separate entities.  National is good at trying to provide motivation, a cheerleader of sorts.
cons: too much after hours work and slow to change with the times.  Fundraisers are reluctant to share their contacts with each other which results in a very silo and company focused view rather than a customer view.  No team atmosphere in many of the divisions.

review_title: RUN, DO NOT ENTER. YOU'RE WORTH MORE THAN THIS.
pros: I'm not able to recall an admirable, positive experience but for working with Cass Wheeler. He is a man of integrity and unfortunately, his attributes did not trickle down.
cons: Name it and employees will confirm your worst nightmare. This toxic environment continues to cause duress, unnecessary stress, supervisory discouragement and that they strive to be empowered by discrediting and not fueling the positive aspects and potential of employees.

pros: Great mission and values, and surrounded by professionals who truly care about the mission and goals of the organization.  Access to people both within and outside of the organization.  Great benefits and truly value a good work/life balance.
cons: Although not unique, lots of bureaucracy and structures in place that are more difficult to deal with than actually completing tasks.  Huge organization and sometimes confusion about roles, responsibilities, etc, and different departments/affiliates etc can feel siloed.  Again, nothing unusual with such a large organization.

pros: The mission is so important and directly impacts Americans every day. Contacts and external opportunities can help advance your career if you work it. Opportunities to wear many hats and learn new skills.
cons: Not all departments perform to professional business standard or competence. Some upper managers seem untouchable despite visible inefficiency and HR complaints. Serious problem with understaffing, high turnover rate in some areas, glacial hiring process: leads to 1 person doing the work of 2 to 3 full-time staffers for months (or years.) Work-Life balance is laughable.

pros: It's Mission and Vision.  In addition, in general, employees' are very dedicated and passionate about their work.  They are also honest, for the most part.
cons:
Good work is not rewarded or acknowledged by senior management.  Senior Management does not listen to employees.  Moreover, they are not interested in learning new skills, either.

The working conditions are generally poor, too.  Many folks in the outpost offices have a lot of technical difficulties.  

AHA has a bad habit of starting initiatives and then not following through.  For example, a lot of time and effort are devoted to the initial development of an internal policy and then the endeavor will die due to another "flavor of the month" initiative.

review_title: A good organization, but can suck the life out of you.
pros: respected organization, flexible schedule at times, decent pay compared to other non profits, good benefits, feel as though you can make a difference in peoples lives
cons: continuous change to the latest and greatest way to raise more money THIS YEAR... a lot of driving, management seems to manage from reading it out of a book first, bad use of donor dollars on travel to meetings that don't accomplish everything except to get people together because you need to have X number of meetings a year.  work homelife balance can be off at times.

pros: Mission side of the organization is great.
cons:
Income development is unorganized and dysfunctional. 
Senior leadership is more interested in short term gain over long term relationship building. 
Senior leaderships expectations of Executive Leadership and Board is a very heavy life and because of these expectations many bridges have been burned. 
No team work
High turn over
Departments work within silos and do not cross communicate

pros: It's a great cause and a large not-for-profit with great training and good growth opportunities if you have good management. The reputation of the organization gives you great access to corporations and contacts within the community.
cons: Large not-for-profit so can be very "corporate". Lots of turnover and some management is poor. Affiliate structure lends itself to same issues many nationa/affiliate organizations face -- difficulty in communication and cohesiveness. Disparities exist between geographic regions and size of offices regarding titles, compensation, training opportunities. As with many NFP's, revenue-generators make significantly more money than program delivery, and emphasis is placed on revenue generation without being able to provide programs and services to many donors.

review_title: Company Goals Are Great/Leadership Needs Improvement
pros: Everyone is focused on the same goals in mind. Peers are great to work with and grow with at work. The knowledge you learn is awesome professionally and personally.
cons: Continued development of senior leadership and mid level leadership is greatly needed. Depending on your department you have a lot of work and tons of meetings to attend. It is very hard to have a work life balance because you are always working from home to stay ahead.

pros: The mission. Great benefits for a nonprofit, PTO policy, some coworkers, office location, emphasis on healthy food in cafeteria and meetings, and wellness incentives.
cons:
Virtually no work/life balance whatsoever. Hourly employees are expected to get an unreasonable amount of work done during the workday, and several on my floor quietly worked on things at home after hours, and on weekends, to manage. Pain reliever was a very popular commodity to be passed around, as people always seemed to be very stressed, and have headaches. Some employees were able to take advantage of great perks, such as the flexible work policy, and daily walking breaks, but the majority were not due to both reasons of work load and favoritism. Overtime was a very large problem. Even when it is glaringly necessary, and begrudgingly allowed by management, you were treated as if it was a gift given to you. Outlook was not much better on salary, as you are basically working, and on call, 24 hours a day. 


By far, the most difficult part of being at the AHA was the constant daily work of compensating for poor, and highly unorganized, middle management. Possibly, the work load would be manageable, if not for the hours and hours spent constantly fixing the messes, and dealing with unnecessary last second tensions. Often, the same situations with the same individuals would be repeated over and over. Upper management was fully aware, and constantly asked for input on how things could be more efficient, but no changes or accountability occurred going forward. 

At the end of the day, your experience at AHA, like most companies, will be dependent on which department you work in, and how much favoritism upper management grants you. There are some great people there who genuinely love their job, and have been working there for years. On the other hand, the turnover rate is very high, and the reasons for that are easy to point out.

review_title: You will work harder than you ever had
pros: Great mission; flexibility (I worked from home) great benefits
cons: No one in upper management cares about anything but numbers. No concern for outside influences, must adhere to Best Practices no matter what the volunteers say, cold-hearted to employees that have been there a long time. Talk the yak but don’t walk the walk. Over worked - I worked around 50-60 hours a week for most of my 10+years and over 15 weekends a year at events with no concern from management (this is at the affiliate level, most National employees seem to have a good life/work balance)

review_title: Sadly it’s an unengaged, uninspired and highly wasteful environment @ the National Headquarters
pros: Easy for the most part – just be there in body and occasionally work
cons: Non challenging & Non Productive - So many people are disengaged with some having side businesses or so many outside of work interest that nothing meaningful occurs

job_title: Youth Market Director in Robbinsville, NJ
pros: Truly feeling that what you do is making an impact on the lives of others is one of the best feelings ever.
cons: There are plenty of times that you are putting in more hours that what you are supposed too.  At the end of the day, it's hard to accept that the outcomes of fundraising is sometimes out of control.

review_title: AHA's striving to the be the BEST Organization YET!
pros:
The American Heart Association is an organization dedicated to improving the lives of ALL Americans by reducing one's risk of heart disease and stroke.  

In addition, it focuses on creating a healthy working environment for its employees as well.

Therefore, it focuses on both improving its internal and external practices to make its environment and procedures more conducive to achieving success..
cons: Downside for working with the American Heart Association is its fear of taking risks as it relates to addressing social determinants of health.  It's time to BE BOLD and LEAP....that what it's going to take.

review_title: Overall, a great place to work
pros:
Tremendous benefits, including generous PTO accrual and 403-B contributions, and good medical.
Fulfilling work, lots of training and professional development opportunities.
Positive atmosphere and good teamwork among co-workers.
Continually adapting to be relevant and stay current.
cons:
Work-life balance is the biggest downside. You work a lot and wear many hats. I do not mind hard work, but I do not want to be set up for failure with too much on my plate and unclear / unfocused goals.
Lots of reductions in force in recent years with downturn (including my former position).
Opportunities for advancement are limited outside of fundraising.

review_title: It did not offer all that I wanted it to offer.
pros: The best reason to work at American Heart Association is because all of the tasks you are assigned will be extremely easy. The skill-set level you need to do any job  there, you learn before high school during candy fundraisers.
cons: The downsides are endless at American Heart Association. Pay is not nearly enough to live happily, even at advanced positions. The tasks are so easy you get bored within the first couple hours. The employees are all, or 99% women who don't practice what the association preaches.

review_title: I liked their mission, but management was the worst I’ve experienced in any job
pros: Some coworkers were supportive, helpful and team-oriented. Their mission is a noble one and something worthwhile to support. The hours were decent (under 40/week)
cons: Management was disorganized, condescending and lacked the people skills necessary to lead their employees. The culture was stressful and communication was sometimes disrespectful.

pros:
Very meaningful mission
Good benefits
Management strives to keep AHA relevant and progressive and focused on obtaining the mission
Dedicated staff
cons:
Upper management needs to take a stand that every program idea is not worth investing staff time and donor dollars in. We dont want to waste a single dollar on ideas that don't move AHA toward the mission. Staff end up working on efforts that don't give results over and over again. It gets disheartening.
Its a non profit. Don't expect to get rich working at AHA. If money is your driver, work somewhere else.

pros: Opportunity and access to learn advanced databases, computer skills to assist with managing or projects.   Most employees especially those who have been here are pleasant to work with.
cons: Staff retention, very high driven, can be very stressful and political.    Pay is not comparable to other similar companies in this area especially for the work expected.   Lack of transparency in positions.  Oftentimes you end up doing many other positions.

pros: Coming to AHA I soon realized this is a non-profit that runs its business like a for profit and this is a pro. The organization truly seeks out innovation and is constantly evolving to keep up with the changing environment. One examples is the organization's investment in a virtual work environment no matter the staff level. This is a huge perk allowing staff to work where they live and they achieve a healthy balance of office based staff and home based staff.
cons: AHA offers competitive benefits but with a predominantly female work force the maternity leave benefit is lacking. Staff can take short term disability but in short there is no paid maternity or paternity leave offered as is available in many corporate structures.

pros: The mission as far as I can tell
cons:
Lack of proper training
cattiness
lack of dynamic leadership
old best practices

pros: A few years ago, I had a great boss.  She made the mission of the AHA come alive leading its food program.  She was an outstanding mentor and did good things.  That was my best AHA experience.
cons:
Today, the AHA has shockingly bad management - unprofessional, unqualified and wasteful. Senior management will have you chasing your tail in an abusive environment.  You won't learn or do anything you will be proud to take to another job. Its declining reputation may keep other employers from hiring you.

It breaks my heart that donor dollars go to paying for celebrity endorsements, entertaining, travel, etc,  AHA executive salaries and perks rival or surpass those you'd find in the C-Suite of Fortune 100 companies.

pros: The benefits are great and the mission is very important. Because it's such a large organization, there are many resources to pull from.
cons: It's basically a sales job. The mission is secondary to the revenue. The top managers care more about getting their bonuses than saving lives. They work their teams ragged and don't care about the employees at all. Those who succeed in the organization are mindless and heartless robots. This is the worst place I have ever worked and wish I would have read the other reviews on this site before accepting the job!

review_title: Amazing organization, amazing mission, amazing leadership
pros: I can only speak for the SouthWest Affiliate, because I do feel that every region was managed very differently, including the national center. The AHA is an amazing organization, with outstanding leaders. They truly treat employees as they matter, and I've never worked for another nonprofit that was structured so well. There are opportunities for advancement, growth and recognition. I highly recommend AHA as a great place to work.
cons: Sometimes the fundraising staff can be difficult to work with and tend to have blinders on. You definitely need thick skin in this environment. AHA always speaks about work-life balance, but it needs to be across the board. My colleagues and I put in more than 50-60 hours most weeks.

review_title: Wonderful organization with a great message and brand
pros: The AHA does a wonderful job of respecting an employee's work/life balance. I appreciate that the company promotes from within and many of the upper-level senior management are intelligent, respectful, and professional.
cons:
Unfortunately, due to the economy the AHA's training structure all but tanked. The company's formal training consists of way too many conference calls and an online "university" learning center which you don't have time to take courses on. 

It seems that there are too many chiefs and not enough indians, especially in cut-backs. It feels like they're moving back to a generalist structure where you manage multiple events.

review_title: Run like a for profit company that saves lives
job_title: Fundraising Vice President in Austin, TX
pros: As a young staff person, you get exposure to c-suite level volunteer leadership and access to top companies. I would never have had this kind of experience with other organizations. When they talk about "working with volunteers" they mean working with leaders and captains of industry. Fundraising goals are very aggressive. But our mission is critical.
cons: If you cannot work with executive level leadership, and  through others, this job will be a challenge. There is too much to do and fundraising at this level is almost impossible to do without great leadership skills.

pros: You'll be paid pretty well compared to other nonprofits and feel like you are somehow making a difference.
cons: You will get micromanaged and will have to fight to climb the ladder in a very small organization that appears larger than it really is.

review_title: Great mission. Poorly run organization from the top down. Tremendous efforts will go unrecognized.
pros: Knowing the work you do for the mission is saving lives, providing training, and advancing research. Flexibility, sometimes. Week of Christmas off.
cons: Very poor leadership. Outdated business models. Micro management without acknowledgement of successes, especially of those in support roles. Closed mindedness to change and new concepts in a constantly changing world. If you do have a great idea or accomplishment noticed, your manager will likely have no problem taking the credit.

pros: They are working towards a good cause.
cons: Bunch of micro-managers that are focused on marketing their brand and making their top notch volunteers happy, than actually developing or implementing programs that will help achieve their mission.

pros: The work environment is extremely laid back, and the tasks required of me are simple, well explained, and often times entertaining. I also am able to attend many of the events and get a better look at what the non-profit is all about. Also, the hours required are minimal, which is nice if you're in school.
cons: Unfortunately, it is non-paid internship, but the experience is still great to put on a resume. Sometimes there is not much for an intern to do in the office.

pros: Mission. Training. Networking. That's about it.
cons: The goals are set for you with little input from anyone but top management. Circumstances regarding donors do not matter. A 20-25% increase is expected on all events regardless of donor wants/needs. There is absolutely no work life balance. The job comes first.

pros: Great benefits if you stay long enough to take advantage of them.
cons:
Very toxic environment with high turnover rate poor leadership.

In the 6 months that I was there, I saw over a dozen people come in and then get fired between 4 weeks to 2 months later. The environment is toxic and cliqueish. Middle management leadership is very poor with very little direction given. Environment across teams is toxic, condescending, and verbally abusive.  I witnessed others screamed at and berated by their managers over trivial matters out of their control. Managers also play favorites and set unrealistic expectations for those that dont fall into that category, while putting their favorites on a pedestal and assigning the easy work to.

pros: Excellent benefits, flexible work schedule, generous PTO/holidays. Great mission and dedicated volunteers. Women in top leadership roles.
cons: Power plays, territorial, disrespect of people's expertise as professionals, a lot of back biting and politics to be seen and get ahead. Not a lot of opportunities for advancement. Pay is good for nonprofit, but not competitive in market.

pros: great benefits, decent pay, good mission.  can be a good 1-2 year stint bc hard to last longer than that in fundraising role.
cons: feels slimy to be as pushy as they want you to be.  if you don't  make your numbers you are out.   Watch the job boards - they hire the same positions over and over.

pros: Co-Workers are awesome! Benefits are decent.
cons:
Management in completely skewed and myopic in their ideologies and what they consider to be 'good' work from lower level employees.  A Director and or Admin could be performing at what other companies would consider to be excellent or good, but this same work will be scored at average or fair.  It is almost as though management is trying to 'incentivize' the employee to work even more by giving them lower scores on their performance reviews when in fact they deserve more (at least my manager operated this way).  However, there are some employees who don't even get dressed for work and come in their pajamas and these very employees are protected in some sick and twisted manner by the SVP that manages him or her.   

It feels as though upper level management (Vice Presidents, Senior Vice Presidents, Executive Vice President) are completely far removed from the average worker bees. Hell should freeze over before you arrive 10 mins after 8:30AM.  Management somehow loves to disregard the late nights, weekends and extra time put in by threatening EXEMPT workers to be at work before 8:30AM.  As if 60-70 hours per week were not enough??!!  Apparently management bonuses or salaries are completely dependent on the VPs hitting their internal GOAL WINS.  These Goal Wins are self-imposed rules made up by the Heart Association to make employees work 60-70 hour work weeks at the salary of a semi decent non-profit.  You will hear it over and over again as if it were some sort of creed that has been passed down to them by the EVP and SVPs. 

Management likes to talk a lot about culture this and culture that--but the VPs are the very individuals that have political agendas to stick by, red tape to adhere to and their little games intoxicate the culture of the organization.  If a volunteer does not want to volunteer, somehow it ends up being the employees fault, as if we had control of volunteer schedules.  The moment you contradict the culture or ask for the Christmas party (yes, I said Christmas party!!!) to be called a Holiday party, management and the lower level minions will treat you as if you should be the next person in line to be executed or stoned to death.

pros: Great new mission and communication about how AHA will help shape the culture of the world. Clear understanding of the position and freedom to do your job without micro management.
cons: On-Boarding was rough...guess I started during a change in process and 6 weeks later I am having calls/meetings/training that I should have had week 1. Budget cuts moved everything to virtual and while some trainers have found their way...others not so much. I understand the cost savings benefits but I feel that because this training isn't in person I am treated like an entry-level employee. I don't see how this change will result in retaining new hires.

pros:
Extensive Onboarding
Review to make sure that staff have the tools to do their job
Experienced managers
Allotted PTO
Competitive salary
Flexible schedule upon request
Exciting initiatives
Work with great volunteers
IT support 24/7
Like minded co-worker
A Mission like no other
cons:
Work load is heavy and requires a well organized and focused person
Goals are always set high and obtaining them can be a real challenge
In some markets there is a high turn over of development staff (not all)
In some markets there needs to be more culturally diverse staff and volunteer

pros: AHA has taken an active initiative during these hard times as we are experiencing a global pandemic. Our senior leadership provided us with working from home  initiatives from the very beginning, however is continuously being proactive in providing us with helpful tips and resources for staff and their families during these times. The organization is also working together and has created specific ERGs for staff during these times to help one another and be resourceful and supportive towards one another.
cons: It's been hard to work from home continuously in these times of crisis, however, great resources have been provided to the staff where working from home isn't always difficult.

pros: Great mission - saving lives
cons:
Senior Management is the worst I've experienced at any company. There is no accountability, only finger-pointing and scapegoats (at the lower levels).
It's not what you know, it's who you know. If you do your job well, they will try to get you to do everyone else's job, and if you can't do your job - brown nose enough and you'll get promoted.
Turn over rate is high and growing.
Much of the outstanding efforts by the non-management employees, goes unnoticed and unappreciated; while many managers take the credit.
Micro-management permeates this organization.

review_title: The American Heart Association is a wonderful place to work, our mission is our passion.
job_title: Operations Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
AHA supports employee growth and development and provides you with great trainings and resources to reach your personal and professional goals. 

Employees work well and often with one another and between departments. 

We get one day a year to support other volunteer efforts. 

There is a robust wellness program that employees are actively encouraged to participate in. 

Compensation is competitive in the non-profit sector.

I love ending each work day knowing we are making a difference!
cons: Fundraising can be stressful and goals can be ambitious at times.

review_title: Best company to work for - I will probably never leave!
job_title: Director of Business Development in Orange, CA
pros: So many! Not only are the people who work for this organization amazing, but the benefits and resources provided to employees are incredible! It is very evident that the executive team cares about their employees - especially during everything going on with COVID-19. They take creative approaches to ensure that employees maintain a work life balance and feel supported by the executive team. They also provide many resources for growth/development opportunities.
cons: Currently nothing I comes to mind, but I will say that you would definitely want to be passionate about helping others if you are going to work here (or for any nonprofit).

pros: Worthy cause and nationally recognized organization. The company has good benefits. Well funded scientific studies that impact everyone. Focused studies on women's heart issues.
cons: "Work-life Balance" gets a lot  of talk but no backing. High pressure fund raising tactics may cause questionable conduct among management. Little to no promotional opportunities. More money should go to cause instead of paying upper management's extreme salaries.

pros: AHA/ASA has a supportive climate for employees. We help each other plan and achieve goals and we help each other balance work-life on a daily basis. Compensation is good for as hard as we work and the benefits are really good.
cons: Working occasional events at night or a weekend can be a challenge but once I am there it is always fun and rewarding. And our office does a good job of allowing us to balance that time later in the week for personal if needed.

review_title: I heart the American Heart Association.
pros: At the American Heart Association, I have truly  felt like a valued employee. It is not just the benefits package and pay (both better than the two other non-profits I've worked for), it's the culture. My work is meaningful and my voice is heard.
cons: Some departments have frequent turnover, which can impact the general function of teams. Additionally, maternity/paternity leave is an area where the American Heart Association can improve. Employees should be given more time, with an enhanced policy, after birth and adoption. AHA really falls behind with maternity/paternity leave, although many full-time salaried employees enjoy flexible schedules that allow us to partake in the special moments our family members have.

review_title: American Heart Association is a good place to work
pros: The AHA is a great place to work. It has excellent benefits and allows for career advancement. Working at the AHA allows you to work with passionate volunteers, and you know you are making a difference daily. The AHA provides great resources and tools that allow you to be successful in your job.  Upper management cares about the staff and our important life-saving mission.
cons: American Heart Association consistently receives an award for being among the “Best NonProfits to Work For”.  This is an impressive award.  Be mindful that the negative comments you read on this site are from disgruntled staff.

pros: GREAT benefits AND REWARD PROGRAMS.
cons: Management does NO encouragement..mostly women, so there are MANY cliques involved..managers hire best friends as supervisors..there is VERY little chance for advancement, you dont feel comfortable talking to management regarding personal issues, most programs crash or have glitches FREQUENTLY, the employees are NEVER asked for input, trainings are inadequate, trainer broke down crying on class bc she didnt understand what she was teaching and the questions overwhelmed her. I mean, this place is a nuthouse!

pros: The organization believes in taking care of its employees through it's benefits program and other activities promoting good health and team building. I have worked for the AHA for three years and have had numerous opportunities to move into different positions to expand my knowledge and growth as an employee.
cons: The reality of working for a non-profit sometimes means having limited resources to implement new ideas and or expand more technical-type training, such as tuition reimbursement for college courses.

review_title: Probably the worst mistake in my professional career-RUN don't walk away.
pros: Great volunteers, worthy mission, good pay for a non profit, great PTO and benefits
cons: They hours are unbelievable, no work life balance, "mean girl" mentality management style, micromanaging atmosphere. There is no growth potential. There is never enough and the company has become greed driven.

review_title: It's ran like a for-profit corporation, I feel deceived.
pros: The people on working in Health Strategies are amazing and implement some really great community programs.  Competitive salary, in the non-profit world.
cons: It's all about the "bottom line" and will use guilt or "any means necessary" to get there.  It's not about the mission.  High turnover.  Shady practices that are never officially put into writing, like the best practices, but are praised if it contributes to the bottom line.

review_title: Meaningful mission though leadership is not the organization's strong point
pros: Ability to work from home, good benefits, decent salary for non profit. The families and organizations that support the AHA are often wonderful to work with and make the mission of the organization come to life.
cons:
With every pro I listed above, I can list an equal or worse con. You can work from home and even when there is bad weather, YOU MUST WORK despite the fact that the community surrounding you is not working. Also, work from home staff often feels limited in the relationships they have within the organization. It is nearly impossible to create a team mentality when you see your fellow staff once every few months. 

I have been with the organization long enough to see a lot of turnover. If you do not go from zero, ie no community connections or no strong established working relationships, to 100% in a very short amount of time, the organization will give you a plan. This plan typically entails a certain time frame (often unrealistic) to hit very aggressive goals such as all previous sponsors renewed, all leadership positions filled and event hitting goal. This plan is often very difficult to obtain and thus they are "justified" in terminating you. 

In two and a half years I have had three different direct supervisors (VP level) and two different SVPs. My role was vacant for one year and the volunteers left with a manager who lives hours away to somewhat lead the event. I say lead loosely. I believe that structurally there is something wrong with the leadership of the organization when there is such significant turnover. Staff is only given a raise when they have not only hit a certain dollar goal but also gained a certain score on their yearly evaluation. One co worker was fired despite being the only team member hitting fiscal goal just three months before. 

I do believe there is a culture of bullying and often it is done by females due to the ratio of female leadership to male. It is often unprofessional and seemingly personality conflict based.

pros: Working at the American Heart Association gives me the opportunity to do what I do best everyday.  It also gives me the opportunity to work closely with volunteers from all walks of life who care about improving the cardiovascular health of their friends, families and neighbors.

review_title: If you love stress, being overworked and micromanaged this is the place for you!

The upper management loves to micromanage every detail, there is no autonomy. High pressure sales techniques are common to get donations.  To work here and not become part of their high burn out turnover, you need to be a sheep with no ideas or opinions... be prepared to fit into the mold they've created.  At least 10 hours a week will be spent on internal meetings and trainings, because AHA is always changing the order and processes. If you go on medical leave or quit, your boss is given access to all of your emails and Skype conversations.

review_title: Does great work, but was overworked

review_title: Great Mission; work experience depends on department

job_title: Corporate Development Director in Fort Worth, TX

review_title: Loved the work, loved the flexibility, loved the cause.
pros: Overall it was a very flexible and supportive environment. I was able to have a family, work full time, and adjust my in office schedule to meet my needs via work from home and flexible hours opportunities.  Plus, at the end of the day I was completely passionate about the overall mission and goals of the company. I truly loved and enjoyed my job.
cons: I worked very very long hours, had to travel frequently, and didn't feel the title or pay was commiserate with my job function and requirements.

review_title: The Worst Career Experience in My Life!!!!!
pros: The mission to build healthier lives free of cardiovascular diseases and stroke.
cons: Where do I begin... What a complete nightmare.  If you are looking for an organization that will micromanage the very life out of you to the point that you couldn't come up with an original thought or idea if you had to- this is your place!  Horrible organizational structure, more drama than a daytime soap, back to back meetings, conference calls and webinars to talk about the vast amount of work that needs to be done without actually leaving you any real time to do the work, unrealistic expectations for newly hired employees, excessive amount of focus on "Best Practices" leaving no room for a plan B approach when their plan doesn't work- if the cookie cutter plan isn't working it has to be the employee- right???  More stress and pressure than any one person should have to live under on a daily basis.  Reports- like doing crazy, crazy amounts of reporting- redundant, ridiculous reporting? -  This is your place.  GAP meetings!!!  Don't get me started- these meetings are intended to berate you and pick through every single spec of the project to which you are assigned all under the guise of "trying to help you close the gap".  I have personally witnessed people leaving these meetings in tears and sick to their stomach.  How can this be viewed as helpful?  I worked with 2-3 nice, well intentioned people who I feel blessed to know.  Beyond that, it is appalling how poorly one group of people can behave and how deplorable their words and actions towards others are displayed.  I'm embarrassed to say that I allowed myself to spend almost 11 months in this environment.  I've worked for some really great companies and alongside some amazing people in my career.  This organization is not for people who care about others and want to be surrounded with positivity in their work.  I'm so thankful that I've moved on from this horrible and degrading experience.

That adds up when there are too many layers. The work environment for directors can be described at times as hostile and abusive when meeting with management. You are instructed to bring in the dollars or else. Volunteers are treated like employees instead of people donated their time and resources for the organization.
